title: It's time to add a fifth champion attribute... Mobility.
body:
Champion attributes are there to help new players understand the strengths and weaknesses of champions and I think another trait that new players should recognize and learn to play around is mobility. Some champions are inheritable more mobile than others, and this in turn allows give them an additional option to approach kills/objectives while less mobile champions would face disadvantages in the said situation. Therefore, I think its time to add a fifth bar to a champion's attributes in addition to attack power, defense power, ability power, and difficulty. 

For instance, Kalista, Leblanc, Kassadin and Udyr would be 10, Yi would be 8, Sion 5,  Ashe and Lux 2, Malzahar 1.

Thoughts?

edit: okay maybe I was biased about Udyr.. is 7 better?

and this:
One way we can measure it is through a point system.

For instance,
gap closers get 2 points
movespeed boots get 1 point x duration
teleport/ abilities that lets you get past walls get 3 points
global abilities get 4 points

Master yi would get 2 points for his gapcloser, 3 points becuase his q can be used to get past walls but its not reliable so -1 points and he also gets a rather long lasting ult so 4 points for that for a grand total of 8 points.

This is just one hypothetical way of measuring it.

That difficulty attribute is a leftover relic from when LoL was first released. How difficult a champion is to play is also relatively quantifiable. Does a champion need fast reflexes? Do they need to have above average positional awareness? Do they take a while to get up and running? Are their skills easy to understand or require a more advanced knowledge of the game?

Someone like Singed is a ridiculously easy champion to understand, is tanky, fast(due to being melee), and has the ability to hamper anyone chasing him, which makes him a rather easy champion to play and understand. A champions difficulty also doesn't change based on which items are buffed/nerfed, or whether the champion has skills buffed/nerfed.

Compare that to Elise. She has 7 skills + a passive to understand. They become powerful when using them in combo's, rather than by itself. It's very plain that Singed is a far easier champion to play/understand than a champion like Elise.

All of those things, and more, can be used to quantify a (albeit archaic) difficulty score. You can't quantify a mobility attribute because the game is different from match to match. 1 match you may get a lot of attack speed, so Kalista becomes one of the most mobile champions in the game. Another match, you might not get as fed/farmed and only purchase flat damage items like IE, BT, LW, and hence not be as mobile as other champions.

There's also the fact that runes/masteries would change how "mobile" a champion is. CDR runes, movement speed runes, and ditto for masteries. Is this mobility attribute going to be calculated on a player by player, rune page by rune page, mastery page by master page, basis? That's a lot of processing power just for an attribute that people usually wont even look at in the first place. People already inherently understand champions without looking at their specific attributes. Riven is already a very mobile champion. We don't need an attribute to see that, since we can't just look at the champion using their skills to understand it.

Once again, how do you account for things like CDR or rune/mastery page boosts?

Take your example: Master Yi builds a Warrior buffed jungle blade, and follows that up with a brutalizer. He also has 4 points in Sorcery from the offensive tree(very common: 5% CDR > 5% attack speed). He now has 25% CDR, meaning he can use his abilities MUCH more often. How can you possibly justify keeping his 'mobility attribute' the same as a Yi who doesn't buy those items or use that mastery?

What about masteries and runes that give bonuses to move speed? Do you not think base move speed should play a part in calculating a mobility attribute?

That part about 5% CDR being better than 5% attack speed isn't strictly true.  5% attack speed essentially is a 5% reduction in the cooldown period between attacks.  The real difference is in the hard cap.  The cap on attack speed is a hard 2.5, but reaching that cap with percentage increases depends on your base attack speed and growth, whereas the cap on cooldown reduction is simply a flat 40%, easily reached with two items.

As to the idea of a mobility stat, gap closers themselves are not strictly mobility.  You could artificially adjust for them to give a champion a little boost, but they are completely useless in moving around the map or running away from someone except in very fringe cases.  A champion's mobility is how long it takes for them to get from point A to point B, using whatever means they have at their disposal.

Once again: CDR plays a huge role in whether a champion goes from point A to point B in 10 seconds or 6.

Now lets assume that this magical system of yours somehow calculates a champions mobility attribute on the fly as a game progresses and they buy items/level up skills. Now what? That attribute isn't going to teach new players anything, because it's changing so often. One minute Ahri might be a 4, then the moment she hits level 6, she becomes an 7? Now what if she goes back and completes a morello's, does she become an 8? What about when her flash is off cooldown? Does she become a 9? a 10?

This just isn't a viable concept to introduce. It serves no purpose that either isn't already served in the game(ability to decide how mobile a champion is > easily judged from looking at their level and items), or is too complicated to provide any reliable information.
